Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.

SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1904.

div.head: BLESSED ARE THE PEACEMAKERS.
div.p:
The latest London newspapers to hand, of Saturday last, give full reports of the Premier's speech at Southampton yesterday week, containing the official disclosure of the settlement. arrived at. One rises from its perusal with a feeling of intense relief and satisfaction. It is not too much to say that, by their timely acceptance of arbitration, our statesmen have laid the British and Russian nations and, for the matter of that, the world in general, under an incalculable debt of gratitude; for it is they who have averted a repetition in Europe of the horrors of a conflict commensurate and possibly more colossal in scale than those sanguinary encounters in the Far East which were aptly described in our latest London Letter as "a tedious succession of gigantic carnage." Out of evil good may sometimes flow. Obviously, no adequate reparation can be made to the families of the fishermen whose. lives were cruelly sacrificed whilst in the innocent pursuit of their hazardous calling. But we trust we shall not be considered wanting in sincere sympathy and commiseration for the survivors and the wounded by taking into
The Remington
WHERE
ELSE CAN
YOU FIND
THIRTY
YEARS'
EXPERIENCE?
Remington Typewriter Company,
P. Vivante, Cairo and Alexandria
consideration the result which flows from the catastrophe in the North Sea. In the history of international disputes, as in that of private litigation, precedent counts for a great deal, and viewed in this light it is impossible to regard the precedent just established as anything less than epoch-making. The moral effect of the settlement arrived at upon future differences of a like nature, even when, as in this case, a "vital interest" and the "national honour" are involved, cannot fail to exert a most powerful influence in favour of the preservation of peace. The gain, therefore, to humanity at large is of an importance which cannot well be exaggerated. It may not, indeed, be possible ever to wholly rid the world of the scourge of war, but every successful effort that tends to lessen the occasions when that ultima ratio may have to be resorted to reflects honour upon the era in which it has been achieved, and transmits a heritage of priceless worth upon succeeding ages.

"Have we progressed " is the question which every thinking man and woman are asking themselves to-day. Those who hold that the answer should be in the affirmative ground their contention upon the discoveries of science whereby man's intellect has wrung from inanimate nature such secrets as enable him to control and utilize her forces; they point inter alia to the advance of medical knowledge and skill in combating disease, to the progress of public hygiene, the spread of education, the higher standard of comfort in living, the more humane treatment of criminals and lunatics, and the improved methods of dealing with pauperism. Whilst ungrudgingly according due credit to these and other factors in the march of civilization, it appears to us that the general rise in man's moral ideals is the surest sign of progress; and that this is best evidenced by a growing solidarity amongst the family of nations, of which the submission of international differences to a judicial forum furnishes the most conspicuous example. Tracing back the history of the human race to its origin we find that the state of primitive man was war. Warfare was his sole career and occupation. Every step therefore in the process whereby this innate and inveterate instinct is "cribbed, cabined, and confined" marks a stage in man's progress towards a higher state of civilization. We may still be far away from the time when the lion shall lie down with the lamb, swords be converted into ploughshares, and the world be "lapped in universal law." But though the millenium is not yet in sight, the latest instance of a peaceable adjustment of differences between two great European nations is the most salient and conclusive proof that the goal towards which civilized humanity converges is being, if slowly, yet steadily, approached

div.head:
THE BALTIC FLEET
A BRITISH ESCORT
DEPARTURE FROM TANGIER

div.p: Admiral Walker's squadron followed Admiral Roljestvensky the whole way from Vigo, a distance of five miles. Both fleets were cleared fraction.
The Sissui Veliki, Oslyabia. Adminal Nathimoff, and Dimitri Donskoi under Rear Admiral Poelkersahm have left for Sula.
It is reported that the Russians are leaving Tangier at dawn HMS Victorious and Magnificent have been despatched to patrol the Strait.
(Reuter.)

div.head: STATEMENT BY LORD LANSDOWNE
div.p: Lent Lansdowne, in a communication to the London Chamber of Commerce, said that Russia had met all the representations of Great Britain and the United States in a conciliatory manner. He understood that the Russian Naval Commanders had recently been furnished with instructions which would result in them exercising their rights less vexatiously in future. He was unable to find any grounds for the suggestion that the Russians favoured German ships compared with British. It was obviously impossible for any Government to inform shippers whether particular cargoes were entitled to enjoy immunity from seizure.
(Reuter.)

div.head: COALING OF BALTIC FLEET
div.p: The Foreign Office, replying to a question from shipowners, declares that it is not per- missible for shipowners to charter their boats for the purpose of following the Russian fleet with coal supplies.
(Reuter.)

div.head: INTERNATIONAL AMENITIES
div.p: Admiral Rodjestvensky exchanged visits with the captains of the French and British warships.
(Reuter.)

div.head:
FRENCH ARMY
SCENE IN THE CHAMBER

div.p: A lively debate has taken place in the Chamber of Deputies, owing to the revelations. showing that the Minister for War was spying on officers by means of reports from the Masonic Lodges. General André declared that clerical intolerance was still so strong in the Army that he was compelled to resort to external channels in order to obtain in- formation regarding the political opinion of officers. M. Syveton rushed up to General André and battered him in the face with his fists. The General collapsed, blood streaming from him. A wild milée followed between the members of the right and left. The sitting was pedal. M. Syveton subsequently was suspended but be refused to leave, and was removed by the guards. The Chamber approved of the Government policy by 313 votes to 236.
(Reuter.)
The Chamber of Deputies, discussing the interpellation on the subject of secret accusation in the Army, rejected by 279 votes against 277 the order of the day pure and simple.
In consequence of this vote M. Syveton snapped General André in the face.
Finally, the Chamber adopted by 343 votes against 236 the Jaurés order of the day formulating the right to the State to control the officers.
(Havas.)

div.head:
CANADIAN ELECTIONS.
VICTORY FOR MINISTERIALISTS
div.p: The Canadian elections have resulted in a Victory for the Ministerialicte, and have increased their majority.

div.head: GLAMORGAN ELECTION.
div.p: Mr. T. Richards, Labour, 7,995, Sir John Corkburn, Independent and Tariff Reformer, 3,360
(Reuter.)

div.head:
THE "STANDARD"
BOUGHT BY MR. ARTHUR PEARSON
div.p: Mr. Pearson, the proprietor of the Daily Erpres and Chairman of the Tariff Reform League, las bought the Standard, which will thus deprive the Free-traders of their most influential champion
(Reuter.)

div.head: STUDENT DISTURBANCES IN AUSTRIA
div.p: 138 Italian students have been arrested in Consequence of some student disturbances.
(Havas)

div.head:
PORT ARTHUR
GENREAL STOESSEL WOUNDED
PROGRESS OF THE SIEGE

div.p: It is reported that General Stessel has been wounded in the latest fighting. "The result of such fighting is still uncertain.

Reuter's correspondent before Port Arthur cables a despatch of tive thousail words describing the progress of the siege from day to das. He furnishes a remarkable history of the stupendous struggle, and the incessant frantic assaults on the impregnable defences, of which hitherto only glimpses live been obtain-able. The Russin searchlights and star shells seem to have conduced largely to rendering the hard won trenches untenable. From the 19th to 24th August the Japanese lost 14,000, only 206 men being left out of one regiment 2,500 strong. Ben beri raged during the wet months owing to the fermenting of the rice.
(Reuter.)
A British steamer, which ran the blockade At Port Arthur with a full cargo of beef, reports that the Japanese have captured all the main north-east positions.
(Reuter.)

div.head: SINKING OF A STEAMER
div.p: The S.S Gironde has sunk in a collision. A hundred KKabyles have been drowned
(Havas.)
M. Paul de Cassagnac is dead.
(Havas.)

M. de Cassagnac, who was the son of Adolphe Granier de Cassagnac, was born about 1840, and became at an early age a contributor to the mi nor Parisian journais. He soon acquired notoriety by the fierceness of his personal attacks on hie contemporaries and the numerous duels to which they gave rise. In 1866, under the auspices of his father, he joined the staff of Le Pays, of which soon afterwards he became the principal editor. Since then he has been perpetually embroiled in quarrels with his brother journalists and anti-Bonapartist politi cians. It would be difficult to enumerate all the "affairs of honour" in which he had been engaged, but his duel with the late M. Gustave Florens in 1869 may be mentioned as being one of the most desperate fought in recent times. M. Paul de Cassagnac was decorated with the Legion of Honour on the Emperor's tete-day in 1666, and in July, 1869, was elected a member of the Conseil Géneral for the department of Gers. On the declaration of war against Prussia in August 1870, M. Paul de Cassagnac, who was still suffering from a recent wound in the chest, and who had just been appointed a Major of the Garde Mobile of the department ot Gers, preferred to enrol himself as a volunteer in the first regiment of Zouaves. Taken prisoner at Sedan, he was imprisoned eight months at Kosel in Silesia. On recovering his liberty he went to Venice for the benetit of his health, and afterwards established in the department of Gers L'appel au Peuple, a political Journal which met with considerable success. Returning to Paris in January, 1872, he resumed the editorship of Le Pays. In July of that year he was condemned to a week's imprisonment, and to pay a fine of 100 francs, in consequence of his duel with M Lockroy. On July 7, 1873, he fought a duel on the Luxemburg frontier with M. Ranc, a Paris journalist, both combatants being wound led, and M. Rane disabled. He was tried in Paris, July 2, 1874, for the publication in Le Pays of articles calculated to disturb the public peace, and to stir up hatred and con tempt between citizens. M. Paul de Cassagnac undertook his own defence and obtained la verdict of "Not Guilty," a result which was regarded by the Bonapartists as signal triumph. In 1874 he published in his journal a series of violent articles in refe rence to the capitulation of Sedan, the whole responsibility of which was thrown on to General Wimpffen's shoulders. 'The General accordingly instituted a prosecution for libel in the Assize Court of the Seine, but M. Paul de Cassagnac wasacquitted by the jury (Feb. 1875). On November 24, 1875, he delivered at a meeting at Belleville a speech in which he contended that the restoration of the Empire was the essential condition of tho welfare of the people. The Pays and other newspapers were prosecuted for printing a report of this discourse, but they were all acquitted. M. Paul de Cas sagnac was returned to the National Assembly by the arrondissement of Condom in the Department of Gers, at the general elections of February, 1876, and October, 1877. The latter election was annulled by the Chamber, November 11, 1878, but in the following February M. de Cassagnae was elected, and he has been at subsequent general elections. Of late years his fiery zeal had somewhat abated chiefly on necount of the unfortunate dissensions in the Bonaparte family, but during the Boulangist agitation he sided strongly with the party of the late General, and in the September elections of 1889 his followers were directed to support Revisionist candidates wherever Conservatives failed to present themselves. In 1884 he ceased editing the Pays, and founded the Autorité, in the columns of which he constantly attacked the present Republican order.

ELECTRIC LIGHT. LIFT.- MODERATE CHARGER

div.head: MAIEH SANIEH
div.p: The staff of the Maieh Sanieh will leave Alexandria for Cairo tomorrow.

div.head: Pariah Dogs
div.p: Stray and ownerless dogs found in the Karmous distriet. on the 7th inst. will be poisoned by the Alexandrin police.

div.head: LAND AND MORTGAGE OF EGYPT
div.p: An interim dividend at the rate of 9 percent for the six months ended September 30 is declared.

div.head: QUADRUPLE MURDER.
div.p: Aly Bey Khouley and three others have been shot at and killed at Dessouk. The murderers are still at large.

div.head: THE ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY
div.p: has accepted the tender of the Val de Travers Company for asphalting a portion of Kaied-el-Gohar street at the rate of P.T. 11 per metre.

div.head: ALHAMBRA.
div.p: Weather permitting, a musical matinée will be given in the garden of the theatre to-morrow at 4 p.m. In case of rain a variety performance will take place in the theatre.

div.head: POST OFFICE FRAUDS.--
div.p: An inquiry is being held by the Post Office Administration with regard to the disappearance of L.E. 300 from the foreign money-order office at the Beba post office.

div.head: MENSHAWI'S PHILANTHROPY.-
div.p: According to our native contemporaries, Menshawi Pasha has constituted a wakf bringing in an annual income of 1,500 francs for the benefit of the French Hospital at Cairo.

div.head: GHIZEH ZOOLOGICAL GARDENS.
div.p: A magnificent pair of East African zebras arrived at the Ghizeh Zoological Gardens yesterday. They are very beautiful creatures and will form an important addition to the treasuresof the "Zoo.

div.head: ESCAPE FROM TOURAH
div.p: A prisoner at Tourah Prison, who was sentenced to penal servitude, escaped three days ago and threw himself into the Nile. He was shot at and killed by a prison guard as he would not surrender.

div.head: THE PORTUGUESE GUNBOAT Rio Lima
div.p: (Com. mander Arthur José dos Reis) arrived at Port-Said on Thursday from Lisbon. She will leave on Monday for Macao. The commander visited H.E. Mustapha Ibadi' Pasha, Governor General of the Suez Canal.

div.head: H.MS. Hermione, second-class cruiser
div.p: (Capt. J. B. Eustace), arrived at Port-Said yester-das outward bound for the East Indies station. 'The captain, officers, and crew will change over into H.M.S. For, whose present complement will return to England in the Hermione.

div.head: THE GREEK FLEET.
div.p: Bell's Asia Minor Line placed the S.S. Bear at the disposition of members of the Greek community who wished to meet the Greek Syuadron on its arrival. The charge per head was PiT. 10 and all the money thus collected will be devoted to the Greek Fleet.

div.head: EGYPTIAN INSTITUTE.
div.p: There will be a meeting of the Egyptian Institute on Monday next, at 3.30 p.m. M. Legrain will lecture on the recent discoveries at Karnak. Professor Arva-mitakis will discuss St. Menas. Moses' Wells will be dealt with by M. Georgindis, and the Egyptian Echnides by M. Fourtan.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL.-
div.p: On the 31st ult. 12 vessels passed through the Suez Canal. Of these, 8 were British, 1 German, 2 French, and I Austrian. The transit and passenger dues for the day amounted to 418,172.51 frs. The total transit and passenger dues collected during last month on 380 vessels amounted to 10,260,079.92 frs.

div.head: MESSRS. REINER AND BINDER
div.p: have greatly enlarged their photographic studio at Alexandria and have much improved the exhibition of their artistic photographic products by the arrangement of their rooms and the alteration in the windows, where the photos are now displayed to the greatest advantage. Their exhibits of oil-paintings and water colours are very fine and well deserve a visit.

div.head: COAL IMPORTS.-
div.p: The imports of coal into Alexandria from the 1st January to the 3rd instant amounted to 889,168 tons, as compared with 841,948 tons during the corresponding period last year. Of this total, Newcastle sent 180,593 tons, the Welsh coaling districts 518,924 tons, the Scotch districts 98,793 tons, and Yorkshire 51,788 tons, while the imports of other qualities came to 44,370.

div.head: THE NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT
div.p: has issued the following notice to the London Press: "The National Bank of Egypt announce that the scrip of the Agricultural Bank of Egypt Threo-and-Half per Cent. bonds can now be exchanged for definitive bonds. Scrip must be listed on forms to be obtained of the National Bank of Egypt, 4 and 5, King William-street, London, E.C., and left three clear days for examination."

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL
div.p: Largest 1st class and most comfortable Hotel in Alexandria. Facing the sea. Central Position. Under English Management.

div.head: Hotel Beau-Rivage, Ramleh
div.p: First Class Hotel Situated in finest part of Ramleh, close to Halte Laurens (station after S. Stefano). Magnificent sea view. Promenade on shore. Sea Bath. Restaurant. Buffet, Splendid Garden. Electric Light. Moderate charges. Best Sanitation.
Mrs. LUIGI STRINSCHNKIDKE, Propietress
Telegraphic Address: BEAURIVAGE. – Telephone: 186

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive's reception at Ras-el-Tin Palace this morning, on the occasion of his approaching departure, was largely attended dospite the bad weather.

The decoration of Cairo railway station in honour of the arrival of H.H. the Khedive has begun. The Moudirs of Behers, Dakablieb, Charkich, Menoufieh, and Gharbieh will salute his Highness at the stations where the Khedivial train stops on its journey. A guard of honour, consisting of one captain, two subal terms, 100 rank and file, regimental colour and band, will be furnished by 2nd Batt. Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, to receive his Highness on his arrival from Alexandria. The guard will be formed up at 11.10 am. on Tuesday, outside the railway station. The officers of the Headquarters Staff, heads of depart ments, and commanding officers in Cairo will meet the General Officer Commanding at the station at 11.15 am.

div.head: ARRIVAL OF GREEK SQUADRON.
div.p: The Greek Squadron, under the command of Vice Admiral Condoriodis, was sighted from Kom el-Nadours at 10.40 a.m. to-day, on its arrival in Egyptian waters from Algiers.

The Squadron is composed of the armoured cruisers Psara, Spetsal, and Hydra. They each have a displacement of 4,885 tons, and LH.P. of 6,700, with coal capacity of 600 tons. Their speed is 17.05 knots. Each carries 1 16-knot 3rd-class torpedo-boat.
On entering Alexandria harbour the Squadron was greeted with a salute of 21 guns from Fort Saleh.

Tomorrow at 10.30 am. there will be a Te Deum in the Greek Orthodox Cathedral, which will be attended by the Commodore and his officers, as well as the Consular Corps. The Squadron, after its stay here, will leave for Pirwus, via Port Said.

div.head: THE BALTIC SQUADRON.
div.p: At least seven torpedo-bost destroyers, with 4 convoy of auxiliary cruisers, and possibly some of the smaller cruisers of the Baltic Squadron, are expected at Port Said in a few days' time on their way to the Far East.

While we have full confidence in the ability of the Government to prevent any breach of the neutrality regulations, we should like to have complete confirmation of the rumour that two British cruisers are expected at Port Said.

div.head: FRENCH FLEET AT SHEIK BARGHOUT.
div.p: A curious incident occurred a few days ago. A Sudan Government patrol dhow came into Suakin and reported to, the Moudir, Howard Bey, that a French fleet had entered the harbour of Sheikh Barghout, the future princi pal port ofthe Sudan, and had occupied it !! The Sudan Port S.S. Hawke was ordered to steam there immediately, and Bimbashi Drury, R.N., Controller of Sudan Ports, took the Harke and went to Sheikh Barghout, where they found that the French fleet which was bound for Djibouti had encountered bad weather and put in at the former port. They were transferring coal from one man-of-war to another. The Hawke returned the next day as there was no fear of another incident similar to the memorable one at Fashoda.

div.head: RETIREMENT OF DRAGE PASHA.
div.p: The following appears in a special Army Order:.
El Lewa W. H. Drage Pasha, D.S.O., on retirement to pension is struck off the strength of the Egyptian Army from the 22nd October, 1904.

The Sirdar wishes to express his great regret at the retirement from the Egyptian Army of El Lews Drage Pasha, D.S.O., who has served with his Highness's troops for nearly 18 years, during which time he has taken a prominent part in the following campaigns and actions in which the Egyptian Army has been engaged: Sudan, 1889, action of Toski; Dongola expedition, 1896; Nile expedition, 1897, capture of Abou Hamed and subsequent occupation of Berber; Nile expedition, 1898, battle of Khartoum; Nile expedition, 1899. El Lews Drage Pasha, D.S.O., has held the appointment of Staff Officer Supplies and Stores, Frontier Force, Deputy Assistant Adjutant-General, Headquarters Staff, and Coned troller of Stores, Sudan Civil Administration. In each of these appointments the excellence of his work has been most conspicuous, and the Sirdar takes the opportunity of swartaly thanking Drage Pasha for his valuable services, and feels sure he is expressing the feeling of the whole Egyptian Army in wishing him every success in the future.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL YACHT CLUB.
div.p: The "at home" to be given to the officers of the Greek Squadron will take place on on Tuesday, 8th inst, and not on Wednesday, 9th of inst., as previously advertised.
There will be a palling race for the men of the fleet; the handicap of the same to be arranged by their own officers.
There will also be sailing races as in the usual regattas. Class I will be awarded an enamel and gold scarf-pin and Class II. a prize a "piece of plate," which will be decided later.
The handicap will be the same as at the last races and will be published on Monday.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Tabor arrived here this morning from Liverpool, vis Gibraltar and Malta, with pee sangers, malls, and general cargo.
The Khedivial S.S. Mariout will leave Alexandria on Wednesday for Larnaos, Mersins, Alexandretta, Limassol, and Beyrount.

div.head: OPENING OF THE SEASON.
div.p: Sir Stephen Mackenzie arrived here on the 1st inst. this being his fourth consecutive Visit to Assouan.
Sir Stephen, whose health is greatly benefit- ted by his annual stay, remains through the season.

div.head: THE TOWN.
div.p: Further improvements have been made during the summer to the buildings along the river front. The old hospital has given place to a fine modern structure capable of accommodating 30 to 40 patients. The Post-Office authorities have nearly completed their new offices, which, by the way, were badly needed, and another building in course of construction will be occupied by the Tribunals.

With such apparent good intentions on the part of the Government to make the town more attractive, and with a site unequalled anywhere in Egypt, it seems a pity that the much and often abused Railway Administration cannot be induced to change their terminus for a less prominent position, which, as it now stands, is an eyesore to the town. This question, which has often been discussed in the columns of your paper will have to be decided at no distant date, owing to the increasing demand for building land, the only spot now available for this purpose being that occupied by the railway station.

div.head: THE HOTELS
div.p: Both the Savoy and Cataract Hotels are prepared earlier this year in anticipation of an early opening of the season. The Savoy Hotel opens on the 15th inst, whilst the Cataract Hotel has already opened.

To those people who have not been fortunate enough to visit Assouan during the winter months, it may come as a revelation for them to know that in the beautiful grounds of the Savoy Hotel, situated on the Elephantine Island, there are some seven thousand trees of all sizes, including 3,000 large trees of all species, about 500 palms of different kinds, and from three to four thousand smaller trees, including lemon, orange, pomegranate trees, and rose trees in glorious profusion. The whole grounds, of about 8 acres in extent, are beautifully laid out, and form one of Assouan's greatest attractions.

div.head: STATE RAILWAY COMMISSION.
div.p: The sittings of the Commission to enquire into the working of the State Railways will com mence at Cairo on the 9th inst.

div.head: CATTLE PLAGUE
div.p: One new locality is reported infected with cattle plague to-day.

In order to deal more effectively with the cattle plague, the country is to be henceforth divided into four circles, each under the control of a British veterinary inspector. Each circle will then be divided into four divisions, each under a European inspector, to whom detailed instructions will be issued as to the methods he must employ in contending with the epidemic.

div.head: TELEPHONES AT SUAKIN.
div.p: Bimbashi Meyricke, Assistant Director, Telegraphs and Ports Administration of the Sudan Government, has arrived at Suakin from Berber, and is engaged in superintending the erection of a telephone line between Graham's Point and Suakin.

div.head: ALL SAINTS, CAIRO.
div.p: The following notice was given out in All Saints' Church last Sunday morning-

"On and after Sunday next the morning service will begin with the singing of a hymn. This change is made to enable those members of the congregation who cannot yet become seat holders to take their places as soon as the bell stops without feeling that they are in- terrupting the prayers. Seat-holders who wish to occupy the seats allotted to them are reminded that they must be in their places before the bell stops."

div.head: ST. MARK'S, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: Tomorrow (Sunday) the services at St. Mark's, Alexandria, will be as follows
8 a.m.-Holy Communion.
11 am-The Ordination. The service consists of a processional hymn, sermon, litany, and the communion office, in which comes the ordination of the Rev. R. F. Rynd, B.A., to the priesthood.
6.15 p.m.-Evensong and sermon.
The preacher, both morning and evening, is the Right Rev. Bishop Morley, D.D.

div.head: ALL SAINTS, RAMLEH.
div.p: Services to-morrow (Sunday) are:-
8.30 am.- Holy communion.
9.30 am.- Service, sermon, and communion.
6.30 p.m.- Evening prayer and sermon.

div.head: NILE TRIP FOR RESIDENTS.
div.p: The Anglo-American Nile Steamer and Hotel Company ask us to bring to the notice of residents in Egypt, to Government officials, as well as to officers of the Egyptian Army and the Army of Occupation, that their firet departure from Cairo to Assousn for the twenty-days' trip will take place on the 9th December next, by the first-class tourist steamer Mayflower. Though the company's lowest rate for tourists is £40, residents will be afforded a special opportunity to travel by the Mayflower at the exceptional reduced rate of £25, which will include a first-class table, all sight-seeing expenses, excursions, dragoman, etc. The Government permit of £1.4.7. is not included in the above fare.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lord Cromer paid a visit to the Boulao polica school last Thursday, and yesterday his lord-ship visited the Lanatic Asylum at Abbassiah.
The Brigadier General Commanding British troops, accompanied by the senior officers of the garrison, attended the Levée at Ras-el-Tin Palace this morning.
Mr. Webb returned from Assouan on Thursday.
The Rev. Professor Sayce will preach at All Saints' Church, Cairo, on Sunday morning next.

The Hon. Anthony Pelham, Assistant Engi neer, Sudan Government Railways, Suakin, who has been laid up with a severe attack of enteric fever, has, we are glad to say, now recovered, and is leaving shortly for England on leave of absence.
Birch Bey is returning to Egypt in the third week of this month. He is now in London.
The Rev. T.D.C. Pirminger, M.A. (Cantab), has arrived at Mansourah and taken up the duties of Itinerating Chaplain of the Delta (S.P.G.).
Mr. and Mrs. Trevithick are at present residing at their Zeitoun cottage.

Spiro Bey, of the Ports and Lighthouses Administration, was received by H. H. the Khedive this morning at Ras-el-Tin Palace to prosent a copy of his "Notes on the Italian Words in Modern Arabic," which his Highness was graciously pleased to accept.

Amongst the latest arrivals at the Eastern Exchange Hotel, Port-Said, are Mr. Spong, Mr. C. B. Ostberg, Mr. A. C. Aort, Mr. F. J. Surur, Mr. A. Perey, Mr. Trevithick, Hanna Bey Bacoom and son, Mr. J. div.head: ATBARA-RED SEA LINE,
div.p: Bimbaahi Lord, R.E, arrived here from Shendy via Barber on the 10th inst, and took over the duties of acting Chief Engineer, Sudan Government Railways, Suakin, in place of Bimbashi Sowerby, at Railhead.

Miralai Macauley Bey, Director of Sudan Railways, leaves here to-day by the S.S. Mahallah for Sues and goes thence to Cairo on urgent business connected with the Red Sea Atbars line. He is accompanied by his private secretary, Mr. Gaiger. They will be absent from Suakin only for a few weeks. During the absence of Macauley Bey from Suskin Bim bashi Longfield, R. E, will act as Director of Sudan Railways.

The British S.S. Thorndey, from Cardiff, arrived here on the 10th inst. with a consignment of 3,500 tons of coal for the 'Atbara-Red Sea line. On entering the harbour she slightly struck a reef bat sustained no damage. She leaves to-day for Kurachee, for orders.

The British S.S. Mooristan arrived here from England on the 16th inst. with a largo consignment of rails and a new condensor in place of the one which was wrecked in the Afghanistan some months ago. She also brought four English permanent way inspectors for the Red Sea Atbara line.

div.head: ABBAS HELMY THEATRE.
div.p: We would remind our readers that this evening takes place the second performance of Verdi's La Forza del Destino at the above theatre. It is a production well worth going to hear.
To-morrow afternoon a matinée perform ance of Aida will be given.

div.head:
ARMY OF OCCUPATION
KING"S BIRTHDAY REVIEW
div.p: The following article appeared in the Morning Post of Saturday last. It will be remembered that some letters on this same subject appeared in our columns last year.

British soldiers in Egypt are no doubt looking forward with loyal enthusiasm to the approaching celebration of King Edward's birthday in Cairo. They will be eager that it should lack nothing of the splendour and enthusiasm of former occasions, and in that sentiment we all join most warmly since no one doubts that each day of our Monarch's reign adds to the affection in which he is held by his people. Soon after the celebration last year a suggestion was made that the choice of a review ground in Cairo might be more tactful and judicious. There is no difficulty in finding a place whereon to present all the ceremonial of a review without the slightest risk of provoking adverse comment. 'The troops might be massed at Abbassieh, or on the racecoarse, or at Ulena, for any of these places would be suitable. But the Abdeen Square is in full view of the Kherlive's palace, and to hold a purely British demonstration there, especially as it is so essentially military in character, has been deemed a tactless thing, capable of being gravely misunder stood by a sensitive people whose goodwill it should be our highest aim to encourage by every means in our power. We are certain no British officer or representative contemplated the possibility of offence being given when the selection of Abdeen Square as a review ground was first made. It was chosen because it was most central, yet the fact that the space is somewhat limited for the purpose and that better ground can be found elsewhere may give some excuse for the feeling of suspicion in Egyptian minds that if not espressly intended as a demonstration of power, it is at least an indication of mere indifference to native sentiment. In such a caso as this it is hardly necessary to argue whether the feeling
of disapproval is justifiable or otherwise. The mere fact that it has arisen is the most complete reason for taking the necessary steps to convince the Khedive and his people that we are not only willing, but eager to remove the slightest cause of misundorstanding. For it is the natural aim of wise British policy in Egypt to make the occupation which financial and political circumstances rendered necessary a boon to the country in every sense. We know from the infinite variety of our experience in India and elsewhere that this is not impossible that, indeed, it is comparatively ensy to make native rulers and their people so warmly appreciative of the substantial advantages of British alliance that they overflow with loyalty to the British Throne and are eager at all times to share in the honour of its defence. The secret of our success has been a desire to act with absolute justice and to show the most complete respect for native sentiment. In the case of Egypt there are special reasons why we should be considerate. We are not there as arrogant conquerors, but as supporters of the reigning dynasty. We entered in that charaoter, and have been able to silence the jealous clamour of other nations for our withdrawal by pointing to the fact that every step taken to strengthen the financial condition of the country and to develop its material resources has had the sup port of the Khedive and his chief advisers. Our function is to aid and to protect, because the peaceful progress of Egypt is so closely bound up with the security of our "main road to India' that we can never be indifferent to what is happening in the country. So much has been done by the genius of such men as Lord Cromer, Lord Kitchener, and Sir William Garstin that those who look at the results without examining the conditions under which they have been accomplished may not realise how largely • British energy is indebted to the Khedive's favour.The difference it makes is that we are enabled to deal with a people who are friendly instead of having to guard ourselves at every step against hostile sentiment and sullen resistance. British officers have taught Egyptian conscripts how to bear themselves with honour in war, but the knowledge that their own native ruler wished I them to be faithful mado them apt pupils under our instructions and trusty during expeditions of great hardship and difficulty. So, too, all the great irrigation works and schemes of reform in which we have been engaged have prospered largely by reason of the confidence in their purpose inspired by the Khedive's participation. It is not only a duty which we owe to the Egyptian people, but also the highest policy to foster this confidence by the most harmonious co-operation and the greatest care to refrain from any acts capable of misconstruction. We may justly claim to have done much for Egypt during the years of occupation, and the excellent feeling which has been created ought on no account to suffer prejudice through any want of readiness to profit by a warning that in one or two matters we have failed to give adequate consideration to native sentiment. It will be so easy to avoid offence in the choice of a place for future birthday reviews that this reminder of what was said last year will, we trust, be sufficient to ensure a change.

div.head: HELOUAN.
div.p: The Grand Hotel, Helouan, opened its doors on the 1st November. Many applications for rooms have been received and there is every prospect of a very good season. The magnificent hall which has been built during the summer is the admiration of all the visitors staying already at the Grand. Amongst these we notice Mr. and Mrs. Pettigren, Mr. A. B. Biddulph Myddelton, Mr. S. Manuel, Mr. Schwerin, Mile Rossano, Mr. A. Rossano, Mr. A. H. Fisher, Dr. Overton Hobson, Dr. R. F. Campbell Ward, Mr. Sidney Halifax.

We are asked to remind our readers that special terms are made for residents desirous of passing the week-end at Helouan, and to make use of the golf links and the golf club- house of the Grand Hotel, also that special return railway tickets, including luncheon at the Grand, are now issued at Bab-el-Louk station, Cairo, and at the Grand Continental Hotel, at the rate of P.T. 20 each.

div.head: EGYPTIAN PAPYRI
div.p: The celebrated papyrus found in a Greek tomb at Abusir by Dr. Borchardt, containing the lost poem, "The Persians," by Timotheus of Miletus, has proved a most difficult subject for philologists. The text is, from its extreme age, very faint, the papyrus also torn and damaged, and the style, and even language, of the author quite now in portions of the work.

The editio princeps was by Professor von Wilamowitz Moellendorff, and recent workers upon the facsimile of the papyrus have not appreciably advanced our comprehension of the manuscript, beyond his primary version. In the American Journal of Philology Professor Basil S. Gildersleeve has printed a consider- able number of illuminating comments upon various difficult parts of the text. From his remarks it would appear that unless another copy is found it is unlikely that a connected and intelligible translation of the new literary treasure can ever be made.

It is curious that the fragments published by Messrs. Grenfell and Hunt of the famous lost tragedy by Sophocles, "The Niobe," short as they are, have decided an important point in the history of ancient art, for they prove that the well-known fresco at Pompei is really a picture of a scene in this play.

Professor Goodspeed, who, in the "Chicago Studies in Classical Philology" published a number of fiscal papyri from Karanis, has also edited a short medical fragment in the American Journal of Philology.

The series of papyri discovered in the Fayoum which are given in the 4th volume of "Oxyrhynchus Papyri'' distributed to subscribers to the "Egypt Exploration Fund" this autumn, will always be considered chiefly in connection with the "New Sayings of Jesus," which will doubtless produce many volumes of commentary and controversy. It contains several important classical fragments, the most valu- able of which is the epitome of some of the books of Livy's "Roman History."

The Greek fragments present precious specimens of lost works, especially the portions of Pindar's Parthenia, and an ode also probably 1 penned by him; and a much damaged text of the argument to Cratinus' lost comedy the "Dionys Alexandros;" and a part of a treatise upon musical scales by Aristoxenus.

The pieces, unfortunately, of Greek texts are all extremely short, and with the exception of a legal document containing a certificate of pagan sacrifice, doubtless obtained by some personage suspected of Christianity, are necessarily quite incomplete. This is the third specimen of these libelli, and their phraseology is now clearly known.

The abstract of chief events from parts of Livy is a much more valuable find. Half of it covers Books 48 to 55 of his famous work which are lost, though a brief summary of them, quite different from that in this new papyrus is extant.

The period described is from B. C. 150-187 and is of great historical interest for therein occurred the third Punic War and the fourth Macedonian one, also the Achaean and Spanish campaigns, The, new epitome being. strictly chronological, which the previously known one was not, will be of great use to historians. It contains an enumeration of the Consuls for each year, and a close study. of it may lead to a final decision as to whether some authors who have been sup- posed to have been merely copyists of Lávy, may not have, as probably he did, founded their works upon the Consular archives, which were in existence, and gave not merely the annual consular names and Fasti, or events which most distinguished their years of office. If so the similarity between such historical records and the "Eponym Canon'' of Assyria becomes most striking.

The greatest light given by the papyrus is upon the Spanish War, for which existing information such as Appian was very con- fusing, but the whole decade from B.C. 150 to 140 now becomes brilliantly clear.

The numerous legal statistical documents, chiefly of Roman times, need special study. The two petitions to the Emperors Septimus Severus and Caracalla are likely to be most useful to jurists, whilst the tour of inspection in Lower Egypt about A.D. 50 will be equally welcome to geographers. It, when compared with M. Amelineau's Geography of Coptic, Egypt and Vicomte de Rouge's Geography of Lower Egypt, will decide several questions of interest.

The list of towns and villages in the Fayoum revealed to us by the new papyri continually augments, and others may be added from the papyri published in the "Bulletin Correspondence Hellénique" by M. Pierre Jouguet, and various other sporadically edited documents from the same district.

*The Imperial Dearest published in Griechische Urkunden No. 140, and there attributed to Trajan, proves to be Hadrian's, whilst the Luperial Edies given in Grenfell and Hunt's "Fayoum Towns and their Papyri" No. XX. as being from Beverus Alexander. Herr Dessau, in the "Revue de Philologie", has stated excellent reasons for assigning to Jalian. It concerns the abolition of the so-called voluntary tax known as the "Aurum Coronarium."

div.p: The Editor of the Egyptian Gazette will be pleased to receive communications dealing with matters of local interest, for publication. Notes of events occurring in the Provinces are especially welcome.
All communications should be sent to THE EDITOR," and be accompanied by the Writer's Name and Address, not necessarily for insertion, but as a guarantee of good faith.
The Editor will not undertake to return any Contribution accompanied by a stamped and directed envelope.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain necessary limits - free discussion.

div.head: THE FUTURE OF THE EGYPTIAN
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir, I have just read, with much interest, a leading article in your issue of last Friday week, dealing with the future of the Egyptian. The writer admits that Egypt is flourishing and developing in almost every direction, but that the Egyptians themselves do not appear to be sharing as they ought to do in the general advance. There is some truth in this last statement, but they really share in this advance more than any European imagines. It is only natural that Egypt should be in a greater state of prosperity than the Egyptians themselves. The familiar expression "born in Egypt" has been and will always be true of our native country, and if it has been hidden for a time it was only due to bad government, and the English did not find great difficulty in getting it out, because nature has endowed Egypt with the wonderful Nile and good
climate.

But in the case of the Egyptian it is different. He has been cruelly handicapped till about thirty years ago. He was ill-treated, over- taxed, underpaid, misgoverned, and indeed he suffered beyond description all that tended to lower man's soul down to the ground. It is quite unfair to expect him to compete with the Europeans of today after such a short time of freedom and good rule. For what is a quarter of a century in the life of a nation
Nevertheless the Egyptian has made a marked progress in every direction. As an example I give the following incident:-

I know a Copt personally well in Upper Egypt who was taught about thirty-five years ago, in a kuttab, how to write and read Arabic, also elementary arithmetic. That was all; he did not even know that there was such thing as Arabic grammar. The blind teacher used his unfortunate stick far too much. The kuttab was far dirtier than our dirtiest stables of to-day, and the "scholars" used to sit on a dirty tom mat. The fees were two small loaves of bread a week. It did not matter if the boy came bare-headed or bare-footed or both, so long as he had his galabieh on.

To-day, the son of this Copt goes to a school in the same town which compares very favourably with similar schools here. He is taught by seven or eight masters, studies many subjects, speaks English fairly well, plays foot- ball and knows what a penalty kick is. He would not wear a made-up tie because he thinks it is common. Progress is not less striking in the mode of our living, social life, etc.

When the old tell us their experiences in their early days and try to make a contrast between it and what they see to-day we simply marvel at the difference and wonder if such change can be possible. There is no doubt that the Egyptian is moving on, and that can be easily seen by himself and any foreigner who cares to watch him closely. It is only natural that he cannot succeed to-day in starting a light railway company or suggesting a big scheme. He is like a schoolboy studying, watching and learning every day till the time comes when he will take the responsibility on his own shoulders. But will they let him Yes, certainly, "Egypt is for the Egyptians,"
is it not 1

The Egyptian would be in a better state still if the Government study their interests more than that. It is Egypt which takes nearly the whole attention of the English. It is true that the natives, with all the others, benefit from this, but surely the Egyptian may ask for something more in his own land. The bulk of those millions waiting to be spent will be probably given to "argent" irrigation works. It seems to me that there is only the raising of the Assouan dam which should be carried out soon, and we need not deal with any gigantic works for the next ten years.

The Government does not spend half enough on education. The prejudice against female education has died out completely among the Muslims, and the Copts are as anxious as ever to educate their daughters. But what has the Government done in this respect? Precious little. The necessity of girls' schools in all parts of Egypt cannot be overestimated, and this neglect is sorely felt all over the country. What can L.E. 204,000 do for the Egyptian Ministry of Public Instruction in one year! The natives who belong to the Government services especially those in the moudiriehs are underpaid and underworked. In an office where six clerks are engaged, three would be quite sufficient. They work about 4 hours a day in the busiest part of the year. A native told me that he was better off twenty years ago when he received LE. 3 a month than now on LE 8. There are hundreds and thousands of effelis who draw L.E. 5 a month. Indeed, it is a well-known fact among the Egyptians that the cost of living has almost trebled during the last twenty-five years. But it is only the natives who know that, because the English as a rule lives quite aloof when he is in the districts, and fancies himself in London when he is in Cairo.

It is quite true that he loves his duty and does it well and to this quality Egypt owes its present prosperity, but he does not know the Egyptian outside the office or mondirieh. The latter would like to ask the former to have more consideration and regard for him, take more interest in him and above all trust him, especially if he is young.
The modern Egyptian can only be ruled by kindness.

Let no Englishman listen to what some may say about one community or another among the natives, but let him prove things for him- self and road authorised historical facts or else be will be tempted to be somewhat partial.

The Country Egypt has benefited so much by the English that it can afford to be left to itself for a time. Let them now turn their attention, more than they did before, to the Egyptian himself and see what they can do for him, his daughter, and his son.
I am, etc.,

div.head:
BRITISH RECREATION CLUB.
A BOLD CLAIM.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir, I was delighted to read in a letter addressed to you from the British Recreation Club, and signed by a member of that club, Mr. R. Knight Foley, a paragraph relative to the claims to the Ghezireh grounds. The letter appeared in your issue of November 1 and dealt with the subject of the reduction of the garrison. Towards the end of the letter the spokesman for the British Re creation Club made the following significant remarks, I use the qualification "significant advisedly for inasmuch as the letter was addressed from the British Recreation Club and signed by a member of that club, we may infer that the club means to hint what it intends to be its line of policy in regard to a question which vitally affects all members of the British community of Cairo. The member of the Cairo British Recreation Club writes thus:-
"Perhaps the Ghesireh grounds may revert to the British community, which is now excluded by "Members only.""

The Ghezireh grounds now do, and always did, belong to the whole of the British community in Egypt, and were formally handed over (or let) for the use of that body by H.H. the late Khedive Tewtik Pasha. It is only fair to mention that at the time nearly every member of the then existing community was a member of the Sporting Club, such as existed at the time. But things are very much altered now-a-days, and if any member of the community, who is not a member of the Turf or Sporting Clubs, wishes to use the grounds for either himself or his family, I fail to see who can prevent him-that is, of course, if he wishes to raise the question, and if the question is once raised I feel confident that both H.H. the Khedive and Lord Cromer would be delighted to see the grounds used by the rightful and lawful owners and their families, even although their position does not entitle them to be elected members of the Turf or Sporting Clubs. The annual rent, or hire, paid for the ground is only a nominal figure, in acknowledgment of the ownership.
It is to be sincerely hoped that the British Recreation Club will champion the cause of the British community and will not allow us to be deprived of our rights. I heartily congratulate

div.head: BRITISH TRADE IN EGYPT.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir-Your article in yesterday's Gazette deserves to be pondered over by every Britisher who has any commercial interests in this country. I have many opportunities for observing the baneful influences exercised by foreigners representing British firms. I may mention, as one instance out of many, that not long ago a foreigner came to my shop and wanted me to give him an order for mosquito nets. He informed me that I had already done business with a well-known English firm, and he, to my astonishment, produced a sample of the very article I had been accustomed to obtain. Furthermore, he was good enough to vouch safe full details of the price that I had been charged. On my demanding where he had obtained this information he stated he was not only an agent for the Continental firm but also the representative of the English house. He did his level best to push the article of his compatriots and to depreciate the similar article of the English firm. He even went so far as to offer me the same article at considerably cheaper rates if I purchased it from the Continental house. This is a good instance of the evils attending the employment by British firms of foreign agents. I could give numerous other instances to prove the truth of my statements.
I am, etc.,

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,I am glad to find that my letter on the slackness displayed by my fellow councillors of the Alexandria Municipality has been well received everywhere, and I sincerely hope that it will have the effect which I hoped it would have when I addressed it to you, and that in future our sittings will be commenced punctually, and that such a thing as a sitting falling through for want of a quorum will never occur again.
Yours, etc.,

div.head: THE STATE OF HELOUAN.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir, I was indeed pleased to see by your issues of the 2nd and 3rd inst. that yourself and Mr. Springer have come forward to plead the grievances of the inhabitants of Helouan. As to the water supply, I can only say that it is filthy for bathing and washing purposes, and as to the road leading to the Nile, that two ladies from our hotel drove down yesterday and on their return they were entirely knocked up owing to the hardness of the journey. The higher authorities that be are not possibly aware of such a state of things, or they would take immediate steps to remedy the evil. As what has appeared in your paper may cause uneasiness to intending visitors to Helouan, I beg to state that steps are taken at all the hotels to filter the water and thus render it drinkable and wholesome. This applies equally to the water used in the rooms. and kitchen.
I am, etc.,

div.head: CAPE TO CAIRO RAILWAY.
div.p: The construction of the Cape to Cairo Rail- way is proceeding satisfactorily, and the route which the line will traverse towards Khartoum has been tentatively decided upon. At present (says the Bulawayo Chronicle) the line is in progress of construction on the north side of Victoria Falls towards Kalomo, while the work of erecting the huge bridge which will cross the falls is proceeding from either side. It is hoped by the time the Kalomo line is finished that arrangements will have been made for ex- tending the railway another 250 miles to the copper district north of the Kafue River, and then the project is to carry the line to Lake Tanganyika. The railway will traverse the north of Eastern Rhodesia to the south end of the lake. It has not yet been decided whether the line will follow the eastern shore of the waterway or whether steamers on the lake will be employed to continue the means of communication. The railway, however, will be joined with the Uganda line and then pushed north- wards past Fashoda to Khartoum.

div.head:
CHRONIQUE THEATRALE
TARTUFFE
LES PRÉCIEUSES RIDICULES
div.p: Les alexandrins ont assisté hier à la première représentation de la tournée Coquelin. En dépit du mauvais temps, le pablie n'avait pas laissé une place vide et dès 9 heures plusieurs centaines de voitures encombraient les abords du théâtre Zizinia, rendant la circulation impossible aux piétons.

Dans Tartufe le héros de la pièce ne paraît qu'au troisième acte et c'est avec une impatience pareille à celle du bon- homme Orgon que l'assistance attendait l'apparition du pauvre homme. Quand il entre enfin en scène, c'est avec un ton nerre d'applaudissements qu'il est accueilli immédiatement d'ailleurs le spectateur est saisi par la puissance, la conviction et la finesse de l'acteur. Les moindres détails de l'action sont rendus sveo une vérité saisissante; il faut citer en particulier la scène de la tentative de séduction où M. Coquelin a déployé toutes les ressources de son génie; la façon dont il surprend encore la crédulité d'Orgon malgré la découverte de son infamie forme un tableau inoubliable qui a été rendu à la perfection. Admirable aussi la deuxième scène de séduction, tandis que le mari est esché sous la table, et enfin le couronnement:
"La maison est a moi, je le ferai connaître"
"C’est a vous d’en sortir qui me parlez en maître"

Nous n'avons pas ici la prétention d'analyser le talent du célèbre comique. D'autres l'ont fait avant nous et mieux encore que toute critique ce qui juge pas grand artiste comme un grand auteur c'est l'accueil que leur fait le public. Celui-ci a immortalisé le nom de Coquelin. Le plaisir qu'il prend toujours à le voir et à l'entendre, le sentiment délicieux qu'il ressent à la perfection de son jeu sont la preuve de son génie. Le public du Zizinis l'a témoigné hier par ses applaudissements. Une remarque que d'autres auront faite sans doute c'est que M. Coquelin, tout en donnant à son rôle toute la mesure dont il est susceptible,n'a cependant jamais l'air de faire "une charge". C'est qu'il donne la note juste. C'est qu'il étudie son rôle sur nature.

La chose a été surtout remarquable dans la petite pièce qui a terminé la représenta tion: Les Précieuses Ridicules Bien ne semble devoir être plus arid: à la lecture que l'interminable è se entre Mascarille et les précieuses ridicules et cependant rien ne peut dire imaginé de plas bouffon ni de plus amusant, lorsque cela est mis sur la scène et qu'il y a pour jouer Mascarille aa Coquelin. La passage de l'impromptu a été délicieux et souligné des éclats de rire de toute l'assistance. La dernière scène, celle de la morale a été passée sous silence; et cela vaut autant, peut-être, car chacun peut aisément en tirer la conclusion. Elle est évidente.

Nous serions injustes de ne pas dire un mot des autres artistes qui figurent dans In pièce. Bien qu'il soit difficile de se distinguer en compagnie du maître et surtout de l'éclipse, ils sont de première force. M. Rosenberg a été excellent dans les rôles d'Orgon et de Georgibas, Mmes Devoyod et Bouchetal dans les rôles d'Elmire et Dorine, Magdelon et Cathos, Mile Lepage dans le rôle de Marianne.
Ce soir 1° L'Abbé Constantin, comédie en 8 actes de MM. Ladovic II lévy et Pierre Decourcelle. M. Coquelin jouera le rôle de l'Abbé Constantin. 2° Monologues dits par M. Coquelin.

div.head: Our London Letter.
div.p: Another morning has brought no relief of the tension created between England and Russia
but its

the result of the Russian outrage The victims were buried yesterday, and it is clear that the Russian Government and the Russian Admiralty would have the world believe that The incident like the graves is closed, or at least, that it will be, as Soon as the precise amount of pecuniary compensation has been agreed upon and paid. That is a most unfor tate spirit to manifest just now manifestation is unmistakably expressed in the tull text of the explanation by Admiral Rod jestvensky, which has already been communi cted to Lord Lansdowne, and will doubtless. e laid before His Majesty's Ministers in Cald net Council today. There is a grunk setons Mumour about the document. for stounding commander has actually succeeded an transforming what was at first an unfortu nate incident" into a real naval battle, result ng in a brilliant victory for the Russian fleet. He was attacked by at least two Japanese torpedo boats, of which he sink one, the other was left looking for her consort, and was, no doubt, the boat which the fishermen pretended to believe to be a Russian Where is she now ? Has she vanished to infinite space! Or has she merely taken refuge in a British port. where she is still lurking with the connivance, of course, of the British authorities!
on
this

The Man in the Bus remark overheard Today "Let the Tur pay and apologise. but let the fleet goon. You don't act kindly to a man when you Want to punish him. There's Something warm in store for the cowards."

The wholly uncalled for interference of Germany in the re-adjustment of political relations between British India and Thibet precisely squares with a still more notable demonstration of the intimate and Cordial connection between the Kaiser and the Tsar. Apparently anxious to go behind the regular processes of diplomacy, they have jointly re- vived the old system of strictly confidential communications carried on through their re -pective military attaches at Berlin and St. Petersburg. Each monarch will thus learn the inner mind of his Imperial friend without any over hearing by Ministerial ears. While, for instance, Lord Lansdowne and Count Lamsdorff are engaged in unravelling this or that complication with patient fingers, the Emperors, conversing through their military echoes, may have come to some secret settle- ment of the matter in dispute. There will be no official record of these subterranean opera- tions, even if the two Foreign Offices were so disposed, they could not, in their ignorance, throw any light on the workings of the Im perial minds and consciences. But there is one way, fortunately, by which the intricacies of this personal alliance may be roughly guessed.

When either Power palpably goes out of its way to confer an obligation on the other without self-committal, it may be pretty safely assumed that the Tsar and the Kaiser have been operating on the new machinery. It is a ready conjecture, for instance, that when the Tsar lately reduced the Russian garrisons on the German frontier by three brigades, he did so with the knowledge that the proceeding was based on an understanding with his illustrious friend at Berlin. And from that assumption, it is easy to pass on to a guess that the German Minister at Peking received instructions to prevent, in he could, the ratification of the Anglo-Thibetan Treaty

It is not often that a false issue can be disposed of so quickly or convincingly as the Or that Chinese labour in South Africa would prove hostile to the interests of the British workman. Mr. Lyttleton placed present figures alongside of former allegations last night, and lett has constituents to judge of the value of Radical prophecy. Twelve thousand Chinamen have been introduced into the Transvaal, and See their arrival the number of white men emploved in the mines has been increased by 1.700 Yellow labour, then, seems to be a grievance of which South Africa can hardly have too much in present circumstances One of the subjects upon which we look for emphatic expression of opinion at the Southampton Conference is that of Redistribu- It is most important that the Govern- ment should be left under no misapprehension the views of their followers on this point. Among the rank and file of Unionists there is The strongest possible feeling that the Govern- ment will not be doing their duty to the Country if they allow another General Election be held under the present utterly unfair

The decision of the Scottish Judges to enforce the judgment of the House of Lords which gives the property of the United Free Chur h of Scotland to the remnant commonly kh wh as the "Wee Frees' was only what was "Fiat bex, ruat Justitia" is a
The expected.
against which there is much to be Sand, but the subordinate courts must, after all carry at the decree of the House of Lords
she Final Court of Appeal if we are to have arrtainty about the law at all.

To lay hands on a public property, even with the best intention in the world, is always a tenerarious proceeding. The committee who have used "Hymns Ancient and Modern" with some violence are getting ample proof of this fart. Criticism is pouring upon their heads, mostly of an adverse kind. Men and women

nght up on certain forms of expression people for whom the prayer and hymn-books are the only remaining link between a mono- tonous present and a bright-hued past-are not accessible to the argument that changes for the better have been made.

A serious increase in the numbers of the insane is shown by the annual report of the Asylums Committee of the L. C. C. for the Ver ending March 31, 1904. The figures, which cover London alone, give a total of: 25,948 lunatics for 1904, or 996 more than in 1903, an increase of over 4 per cent. So large an advance is at first sight very alarming, but it must be remembered that we are becoming every year more solicitous for the registration and control of the mentally deficient.
The fact that Kingsway and Aldwych are to he lighted by gas and not by electricity will come as a surprise to "the man in the street,' whose experience of street lighting is contined

to what he sees in the street. But incandescent gas moler pressure has made such headway during the past few years that electricity as a street illuminant has been badly beaten both on the score of cheapness and efficiency. The are light is ruinously expensive, and when the contract period for lighting the City's streets has expired incandescent gas will certainly he substituted In Ludgate circus and elsewhere in the City I beaten the are light, while for side street lighting it has driven incan- descent electric light out of the field, even in districts like Islington, Shoreditch, and South- wark, where the borough councils have every reason to do all they can in support of their own electric lighting undertakings.

To the ping pong eye, the billiard arm, and bicycle stoop must be added the new complaint of "bridgitis." It is the consequence of over- indulgence in bridge, and attacks players, especially those who spend their days and nights in the fascinating game. The symptoms are violent pains in the head, particularly behind the ears.

Mr. John Burns is beginning to find out that it is possible for even the County Council to do too much for his horny-handed protegés. He opposed the building of a new mammoth lodging-house in the Drury lane quarter on Tuesday on the ground that such institutions promoted "an undesirable kind of club life. The man who is in regular work, says Mr. Burns, should be married and living in his own house a sentiment to which the imagination can hear all female Battersea twittering its applause. It does not necessarily follow that if we could evict the celibate sybarites of Parker street and Deptford, the result would be an avalanche of banns or a momentous addition to the domestic bliss of the Metropolis. But on one point Mr. Burns gives a warning which may be well founded and is worth attention. He declares that the combined energies of the County Council, the Rowton House movement, and the Salvation Army are attracting to London more than its fair propor- tion of the country's vagabondage. Some such result is always to be traced when one part of the country begins to outstrip the rest in philanthropic enterprise. Unless provincial cities follow suit to the great strides which London has made in provision for the homeless, we may be confronted before long with a very grave social difficulty.

An ingenious but dangerous attempt was made on Thursday afternoon to solve the "Zutka mystery at the Hippodrome. "Zutka is a large and apparently human figure of the Phroso type, which comes out of a small box in full view of the audience. Some person unknown attempted to solve the problem as to whether it is animate or not by leaving a bottle containing chloroform in the box. The result was that the showman who opened the lid fell unconscious on the stage. Supposing the figure to be human, the daring experi menter might easily find himself the central figure of a trial for manslaughter. A similar attempt was once made on the celebrated auto- maton chess-player. A member of the au- dience called "Fire" whereupon the "auto- maton" rolled frantically about, and betrayed the presence of the man concealed in its works. A story, which is so astonishing that it reads almost like fiction, was told at the Guildhall on Wednesday. It had reference to Cecil Brown Smith, a well-dressed man, who described himself as an electrical engineer, living at Bramah House, Beardell-street, Upper Norwood, and who was charged with begging.

A detective saw the prisoner standing out- side the Bank of Scotland, and in his left hand he held a cigar-box containing matches. He was apparently paralysed, his head drooping on one side, and his right hand hanging limp. He was shaking all over, and his distressing appearance moved the passers-by to pity.

The detective, who had had Smith under observation for several days, described the transformation of the match-seller to a subur- banite renting a villa at £30 a year. In the evening he changed his coppers for silver at Messrs. Salmon and Gluckstein's, and, aided by a conductor, got on to an omnibus, riding to London Bridge Station. There his lameness got much better, and his head became erect, He travelled second-class to the Crystal Pa lace, and usually ran up the station steps two at a time. Then he adjourned to an oyster shop and had an oyster repast. His movements after that became so brisk that the detective had some difficulty in keeping pace with him. Meeting a lady he raised his hat, and with his
"paralysed" hand shook hers vigorously. Smith is said to have made £6 a week in the City, and up to Tuesday was drawing weekly pay from the Hearts of Oak Society. He was remanded.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: Lord Charles Beresford, with the astonishing luck that has accompanied his whole career, is once more the Man of the Hour. Second son of the fourth Marquess of Waterford, he has | d had five-and-forty years of the sea, has helped to make history at Abou Klea, up the Nile, Metemmeh, and Alexandria, and is still nearly two years short of sixty.

It is not by any means certain that he was not at the bottom of the spring cleaning at the Admiralty which has just seen its sequel in the appointment at the head of practical affairs of Sir John Fisher; for when he resigned his Lord Commissionership at the Admiralty by way of protest against a policy of muddle and cheese paring, he gave the Government cause to think hard, and in the end came drastic reform. If Lord Charles was not directly responsible for it, he at any rate hurried it forward by several years.

Sir Compton Edward Domvile, K.C.B., who, as Commander-in-Chief of the Mediterranean Fleet at a critical time for this country, be- comes an even more interesting personage than usual, is a Worcestershire man himself, born on a 10th of October, sixty-two years ago, to the late Harry Barry Domvile. But he comes of the Domviles, Barts., of Templeogue and Santry, in the sister kingdom, and is as good an Irish.nan as need be.

Not but what there is good English blood in him also. The Irish Domviles get their baptismal Compton through the third wife of the first baronet of a 1686 creation. The grantee of that dignity, Sir Thomas, M.P. for 9 County Dublin, took to wife, lastly, Anne, daughter of the Hon. Sir Charles Compton, second son of Spencer, second Earl of t Northampton; and with their son, Sir Compton, second baronet, this baronetcy came to an erd.

The estate went to a nephew, Charles Pock- lington, who renounced his own patronymic in favour of his uncle's, and who inherited, besides his uncle's property, the estate of his cousin, Henry Barry, of the Lords Santry now extinct. Three weeks or so before Waterloo the baronetcy was revived for his son, Sir Compton Pock-9 Olington Domvile, who fathered the second and third baronets, and their sister, long known in London Society as the wife of the Danish O Minister, H. E. Torben de Bille. The third baronet married Miss Meade, daughter of the Hon. Robert, of the Clanwilliams, and the present Sir Compton Meade Domvile, fourth T - baronet, is due to their marriage.

Sir Compton, the Admiral, wrote himself R.N. at fourteen, and, at twenty, was serving on the Royal yacht. Service of another character he has seen, since, in all parts of the world. In the Mediterranean he is quite at home. He was Second in Command there ten years ago. By the way, in connection with his present t business, it may be recalled that he won his promotion to Commander by his dealings with f certain pirates, who thereafter ceased to trouble.

So many hostile possibilities which we do not wish to describe s probabilities loom through mists enveloping the future of a con- flict between Great Britain and Russia that the British Government have shown a wise pre- vision in getting the whole of our naval forces at once into a state of thorough preparedness. A comparatively small proportion of these I would be sufficient to deal with the Baltic e fleet or a possible eruption of the Black Sea squadron. But in view of Russia's evident e determination to imperil the peace of the whole t world, in spite of the studied moderation of our attitude hitherto, it would be folly to trust to the localisation of any further conflict.

But what are the most likely developments of a war between ourselves and Russia? After the removal of Russia's naval power from the , seas, which we reasonably expect, whether it is destroyed at sea or escapes into neutral ports and is disarmed, the long threatened attack on India is the prospect to which Russian Chauvinists seem to pin their faith. But this first means an advance against the 1. territory of Afghanistan. It is somewhat signifi- cant coincidence, therefore, that the Ameer should lately have displayed an anxiety for closer relations with the Indian Government, and there is every probability that Russia's increasing strength in the direction of Herat has exercised a disturbing effect upon the Moha- medan ruler of Kabul, who would be the first to be sensitive of any augmentation of Musco- vite pressure in Central Asia. It is of good e augury, therefore, that in attempting to strike at India any Russian force would seemingly d have to encounter this formidable and well- armed race of mountaineers in the most difficult

country in the world for European troops. Every Afghan is a cragsman born and bred, a splendid shot, and every bit as courageous as the Japanese. Even if they showed any initial aversion from the entry of their country by an Anglo-Indian Army the Afghans would undoubtedly make their mountains a terribly hot place for their northern invaders.

The other contingency which we must look at in considering possibilities of so momentous a character is that Russia may have despaired of success in Manchuria, and may decide to terminate her efforts in that country where she has met with so many disastrous losses, come to terms with Japan, and throw her whole. strength into the Central Asian adventure. There are many Russians with whom the war in the Far East is unpopular, yet who would regard with much more favour an attempt upon India, and it is easy to understand that the desperate gamblers at St. Petersburg might see in a conflict with Great Britain a means of rallying popular sentiment and regaining their damaged ascendancy.

An Army Order has been issued directly giving effect to Lord Kitchener's scheme for the redistribution of the Indian Army. Roughly speaking, the order groups the units in the formation in which they can best train in peace for fighting in war. The conditions of the country, it is pointed out, owing to the spread of railways and telegraphs, have vastly changed since the mutiny, when the present location. of troops was arranged.

The new scheme concentrates the troops according to present requirements and in par- ticular enables all three armies to be trained together in the various centres. Southern India is by no means denuded of troops, though the post of Lieutenant-General of the Madras Army has been abolished. The military arrangements in Burma remain unchanged. The cost of the changes will, it is believed, amount to £10,000,000 sterling, which will be spread over some years.

The death of Field-Marshal Sir Henry Nor- man removes one of the most picturesque and honoured figures among our military veterans. A soldier who had fought at Chillianwallah and lived to serve on the South African War Commission had seen much indeed. It is true that Sir Henry's brilliant services in the field ceased nearly half a century ago, after the Mutiny; but since then his administrative work has been invaluable. It was he who de- vised the scheme that resulted in the creation of the Indian Staff Corps, and thereafter, as one of the governors of India, successively in Calcutta and in London, and as Governor of Jamaica and Queensland, he served the Em- pire well. He might have been Governor- General of India after Queensland had he felt young enough to accept the offer. His may not be a name that will figure in history, but the soldiers and statesmen of his generation, or rather, of his many generations, knew his value,

div.head: 15th ROYAL HUNGARIAN MONEY LOTTERY.
div.p: Under Control of the Hungarian Government.
BY ORDER
of the Royal Hungarian Ministry of Finances the DRAWING 1st CLASS will take place on
24th and 25th November, 1904.
In view of the great demand, those desiring to participate are requested to send in their order immediately to
BANK CHARLES KISS & Co.,
General Agents to the Royal Hungarian Lottery, 92, Andrassy Street, BUDAPEST (Hungary).

table.head: Propsectus of the 15th Royal Hungarian Lottery.

cell.p: The highest prize will, in the luckiest event, amount to CROWNS 1,000,000 (One Million)
The last of these 500 drawn prizes will win the premium.

div.p: GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS.

Oranisation of the lottery. The Royal Hungarian Lottery consists of 110,000 Tickets of which 55,000 will be drawn with prizes and 1 premium. The tickets bear the Royal Hungarian Arma and an English translation.
Drawings. The drawings will take place publicly under the auspices of the Royal Hungarian Government, and in the presence of a State Notary.
Drawing Lists. After the drawings the participants will receive an official list of drawn numbers with prizes.
Correspondence in English, French, Italian, and all principal languages.
The official prospectus will be added to each order and will be sent beforehand on application.

Payment of prizes. All prizes are payable after the drawing in each, on returning the drawn ticket. To our foreign correspondents we transmit small prizes by mail, larger amounts will be paid out in cheques by the medium of banking houses in all large towns of the world.

N.B. To prevent any misapprehension, arising but too frequently in the public mind, we beg to point out that a winning ticket in the Royal Hungarian Lottery, lawfully acquired and paid for, affords its owner the same guarantee for payment as a banknote issued by the Bank of England.

cell.p: FOR ALL CLASSES.

div.p: Participation in all Six Drawings.

The majority of clients prefer to secure at once the right to paricipate in all of the six drawings, which is judicious considering the appreciation in value from drawing to drawing, and the great advantage offered, especially by the 6th drawing, when the largest prizes and the premium of 600,000 crowns are drawn, amounting together to more than ten millions of crowns.

In order to enable the purchaser to secure the full advantage thereof, we are prepared to guarantee such participation in all the six drawings against two equal payments: one payment on application, viz:–
Crowns 80 84 fr. 3 6/8 for one Whole Ticket.
And the other before the 5th drawing, but naturally the latter only to be made in case the number of the tivket should not have already won a prize at a previous drawing.

Every order must be accompained by its value by money order, which please fill out in Crowns, on receipt of which the desired tickets will be sent by return of mail. If you prefer remitting bank notes, cheques, coupons, etc., you are requested to have your letter registered.
All orders should be addressed to
CHARLES KISS & Co.
GENERAL AGENTS TO THE ROYAL HUNGARIAN LOTTERY.
92, Andrassy Street, BUDAPEST, (Hungary.)
